question1: I want to help make a difference in the world - no matter how small. Blueprint connects various non-profits with different objectives with students to deliver technology services.  Helping these organizations achieve their goals also helps make the world a better place. It would also expose me to various problems that real people face, such as inclusion for people with cognitive disabilities, or plastic pollution in developing countries. It would help me become a better designer.
question2: I've volunteered with Big Brothers Big Sisters to help kids who are new to Canada integrate to the new environment. I came up with various fun educational activities which led to receiving Volunteer of the Year award. I have also volunteered for the University of Waterloo as a engineering ambassador, leading the Shadow Day program for two years. Lastly, I've worked at Multiple Sclerosis Society of Canada.
question3: I'm most proud of the design system that I established at a startup I worked at. Design was relatively new at the company and thus had a huge design debt. I decided to tackle that problem by establishing a design system that would reduce the design debt. I researched design systems, interviewed stakeholders, and created a functional design guide as a starting point. The final result significantly reduced design time, lead to happier designers, and less inconsistencies in the product.
question4: I once told an inappropriate joke during an interview, which lead to me receiving an offer for that job.

dropdownQuestions.question: Where did you hear about us?*

question1: I love getting involved with clubs and teams on campus, where I can exchange ideas, contribute meaningfully and meet interesting people. Having heard a lot about the culture at Blueprint, I want to join the organization so that I can meet like-minded people with whom I can share my passion for volunteering. I enjoy volunteering greatly, and try to volunteer for causes that I support as much as I can, whenever possible. I feel that joining Blueprint would allow me to combine my love for volunteering with technology, and actually build something relevant in a social space. In addition to this, Blueprint has a supportive team environment and strong mentorship program. Along with being able to contribute to the team, I feel that I will be able to learn a lot from my team members and build meaningful relationships. I resonate strongly with Blueprint’s motto of building technology for social good.
question2:
I have led the Feds Volunteer Centre at UW as its coordinator, and run several successful campaigns and initiatives. My goal was to raise awareness about volunteering around Kitchener-Waterloo and to promote students to volunteer on and off campus. Through the service, I managed to engage students in 2000+ hours of volunteering at an organization of their choice, in the Winter 2018 term. 
At my high school in Dubai, I participated in the SAATHI initiative, during which my batch-mates and I organized fun events for children with physical disabilities, and attempted to provide them with an interactive and engaging experience. 
I have also spearheaded the PALS initiative at my high school, which was essentially a program to instruct the janitorial and support staff of the school with the basic essentials of English and Mathematics.
I enjoy devoting time to the local soup kitchen, ‘Food Not Bombs’, where I have cooked and served vegetarian meals to the community.
question3: As the coordinator of the Feds Volunteer Centre, I spearheaded the first ‘Timeraiser’ initiative at UW to promote volunteerism – it is like a fundraiser, but instead of donating funds, you donate your time towards volunteerism. I saw this project through right from its inception, up until its end. I implemented useful marketing strategies to spread the word about the Timeraiser around campus and got around 250 students to sign up and pledge a minimum number of hours. All Feds services were also participants in the Timeraiser. Throughout the event period, students volunteered at their local organizations and tracked their hours on our online tracker, with the help of our executive team, to meet their pledge goals. To incentivize students to volunteer, prizes were handed out to the top 6 participants who volunteered for the most number of hours. These prizes were provided free of cost by Toronto Maple Leafs, Clif Bars, Skyzone, etc. That month, 2000+ hours of volunteering were recorded in total.
question4: I can speak 6 languages - English, Hindi, Arabic, French, Spanish and Kannada!

questions.question: Why do you want to join Blueprint?*

questions.answer:
I have led the Feds Volunteer Centre at UW as its coordinator, and run several successful campaigns and initiatives. My goal was to raise awareness about volunteering around Kitchener-Waterloo and to promote students to volunteer on and off campus. Through the service, I managed to engage students in 2000+ hours of volunteering at an organization of their choice, in the Winter 2018 term. 
At my high school in Dubai, I participated in the SAATHI initiative, during which my batch-mates and I organized fun events for children with physical disabilities, and attempted to provide them with an interactive and engaging experience. 
I have also spearheaded the PALS initiative at my high school, which was essentially a program to instruct the janitorial and support staff of the school with the basic essentials of English and Mathematics.
I enjoy devoting time to the local soup kitchen, ‘Food Not Bombs’, where I have cooked and served vegetarian meals to the community.
questions.placeholder: e.g. Red Cross, local soup kitchen, etc.
questions.question: Describe your contributions to any volunteer/non-profit organizations:*

questions.answer: As the coordinator of the Feds Volunteer Centre, I spearheaded the first ‘Timeraiser’ initiative at UW to promote volunteerism – it is like a fundraiser, but instead of donating funds, you donate your time towards volunteerism. I saw this project through right from its inception, up until its end. I implemented useful marketing strategies to spread the word about the Timeraiser around campus and got around 250 students to sign up and pledge a minimum number of hours. All Feds services were also participants in the Timeraiser. Throughout the event period, students volunteered at their local organizations and tracked their hours on our online tracker, with the help of our executive team, to meet their pledge goals. To incentivize students to volunteer, prizes were handed out to the top 6 participants who volunteered for the most number of hours. These prizes were provided free of cost by Toronto Maple Leafs, Clif Bars, Skyzone, etc. That month, 2000+ hours of volunteering were recorded in total.

questions.question: Tell us a fun fact!*

questions.placeholder: (Optional)
questions.question: Is there anything else you would like to share?

roleQuestion1: I have always been comfortable with coding in Java, C++, Python, etc. However, I struggled with front-end development because I found it slightly monotonous. This proved to be a hindrance when I wanted to build my own website. My only option was to actually sit down and learn how to code with HTML and CSS. Thus, I began doing online courses to familiarize myself with the web-building tools. Even after taking these courses, I could not build my website perfectly. Finally, I began working with friends and mentors on web development side-projects so that I could get actual hands-on experience with front-end development. This is when I actually got the hang of coding in HTML and CSS. I even worked on simple projects of my own in order to test my capabilities.
roleQuestion3: At a science fair organized by my school classmates and I for 1000 students, there was a major issue of task delegation. Students on the organizing team did not come forward to pick particular tasks for themselves; instead, they just tried to help with general tasks. Hence, when issues relating to particular tasks arose, no one took ownership of those issues. I created a chart based on skillset and incomplete tasks, and assigned tasks to each student based on what matched their skills. They were expected to report to their task manager each day with updates, and these updates were added to the chart. The chart was also used to track the expected time for task completion against the time being spent on the task (task progress). Thus, tasks were completed more smoothly.
roleQuestion5:
I like to prioritize my time based on the urgency of the task – I rank my tasks in order of what needs to be completed first and what can be completed subsequently. I also like to prioritize my work such that I am ahead of schedule, so that I have room for any unexpected changes or upsets in my schedule. 
Things that help me stay on track are my diary/planner, my e-calendar and reminders that I set on my phone for important tasks. For particular projects, I also like to use a Gantt chart, so that I can plan and track particular tasks in the project. 
For tasks that need to be done with other people, I like to stay on top of things by starting discussions early, so that team members can coordinate their meetings well in advance, instead of delaying tasks until the last moment.
